componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Snap-on Incorporated 2015 First Quarter Results Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Leslie Kratcoski, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jamie, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us today to review Snap-on's first quarter results, which are detailed on our press release issued earlier this morning. We have on the call today Nick Pinchuk, Snap-on's Chief Executive Office
componenttext:
Thanks, Jamie, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us today to review Snap-on's first quarter results, which are detailed on our press release issued earlier this morning. We have on the call today Nick Pinchuk, Snap-on's Chief Executive Officer; and Aldo Pagliari, Snap-on's Chief Financial Officer. Nick will kick off our call this morning with his perspective on our performance. Aldo will then provide a more detailed review of our financial results. After Nick provides some closing thoughts, we'll take your questions. 
As usual, we've provided slides to supplement our discussions. You can find a copy of these slides on our website next to the audio icon for the call. These slides will be archived on our website, along with the transcript. 
Any statements made during this call relative to management's expectations, estimates or beliefs, or otherwise state management's or the company's outlook, plans or projections are forward-looking statements, and actual results may differ materially from those made in such statements. Additional information and the factors that could cause our results to differ materially from those in the forward-looking statements are contained in our SEC filings. 
with that said, I'd now like to turn the call over to Nick Pinchuk. Nick?

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Leslie. Good morning, everyone. As usual, I'll start with the highlights of our first quarter and along the way, I'll give you perspective on our results, our markets and on the progress we've made. In Aldo, we'll move into a more detailed revie
componenttext:
Thanks, Leslie. Good morning, everyone. As usual, I'll start with the highlights of our first quarter and along the way, I'll give you perspective on our results, our markets and on the progress we've made. 
In Aldo, we'll move into a more detailed review of the financials. I believe that our first quarter once again provided strong evidence of Snap-on advancing along our runways for both growth and for improvement. Our EPS in the quarter was $1.87, up from $1.62 last year. That rise reflects an opco operating margin of 16.7%, an increase of 120 basis points. Combining those opco gains with earnings of $40.3 million from Financial Services brought Snap-on's consolidated operating margin to 20.1% compared to the 18.6% registered last year. 
Our operating improvement in the quarter came on organic sales growth of 9.9%. Overall sales in the quarter were $827.8 million, a rise of 5.1% from the prior year and those gains included significant unfavorable foreign currency translation of $38.5 million or 540 basis points. 
Currency is headwind towards last year is likely to continue throughout the year. And if the presence where whole, we'll rise somewhat going forward. But we are very encouraged by our organic growth in both volume and profitability, and we believe both represent a continuation of our strengthening position and capability and of the generally favorable business environment for each of our operating groups. 
For us, the quarter's results are testimony to the abundant opportunity along our runways for growth and have our ability to take advantage as conditions unfold. 
Like in past quarters, environment surrounding our automotive repair-related businesses, the Tools Group and the RS&I group, is generally positive. The changing technologies across the fleet continue to drive the need for new problem-solving products, making those markets robust. 
And now with regard to Tools Group, has enhanced our franchise network with advanced productivity and with innovative marketing, taking clear advantage of the favorability of itself more to existing customers and to reach new customers, all on its way to strong growth. 
At the same time, RS&I has also grown, capitalizing on those positives and utilizing its broader product line to expand and repair shops owners and managers. 
Now C&I serving customers in critical industries. And the most international of our groups does face more variations in the market. European operations are confronted with large differences across the business from the relatively calm U.K. to the turbulence of the Middle East, of the challenges of Russia, to the political uncertainties of newly elected governments in places like India and Indonesia. But as in past quarters, the opportunities outweigh those headwinds. And when combined with our growing range of customer-driven products and with our expanding capabilities aimed specifically at the needs of industries and customers, C&I again showed gains, extending in critical industries and building in emerging markets. 
Besides advances on our runways for growth, we also made progress on our runways for improvement with Snap-on Value Creation in safety, quality, customer connection, innovation and rapid continuous improvement, or RCI, as we call it. Now RCI has become a part of the fabric of daily activity at Snap-on. You can see it in the results. OI margins up. And you can see it in advance like our annual RCI conference have recently just down the road in Illinois. 
Nearly 400 people, almost 40 best practice teams came together to share ideas, vie for awards and celebrate their progress, bringing the learning and the enthusiasm back home to their local teams. 
You can't help but walk away from these events encouraged and convinced that there's great potential for further improvement. 
Last, the environment. Of course, as always, there are headwinds. Market-to-market variations in difficult macros. But despite the challenges, our operations moved significantly along each of our runways for both growth and improvement and you can see it throughout the numbers. 
Now let's move to the segments. In the C&I Group, organic sales were up 9.8%, with contributions coming from our European, U.S. and Asian operations. From an earnings perspective, C&I operating income of $44 million increased $4.9 million or 12.5%, and that represents a margin rate for C&I, up 14.8% and expansion of 130 basis points. 
SNA Europe again reported volume growth, this time similar to that achieved by C&I overall, broad gains in many of our markets led by selling strength and by products that generate real enthusiasm. But SNA Europe's improvement in the quarter goes beyond sales growth and farther than the gains made from past restructuring. Our initiatives to improve productivity with focus on both cost and product development are clearly evident in the operations achieved. You can see it again this quarter. Organic sales were up. Profits. Profits were up more, illustrating the power of RCI even in the European environment that remains challenged. 
Industrial division was also part of C&I rise. It grew in a number of critical industries communities like power generation, mining, railroads and the military. As everybody knows, the military sector remains uncertain. But having said that, we've made the most of the opportunities available. This time, the opening arose with the changing roles of various units as the troops were redeployed back to the United States. Actually, that's a major theme for our first quarter, making the most of the opportunities as they arise amid the turbulence. 
Another big factor in the games in critical industry were expanded product offerings targeted at practical workplace needs. One example introduced in the quarter was the PDX series of air drills, ideal for the aviation industry. Made in our North Carolina plant, these pneumatic drills used in applications ranging from assembly to metalworking, perfect for drilling ferrous and nonferrous metals, plastics and composite materials. The kind of versatility that's so helpful in aviation applications. And the federable trigger provides outstanding control and unparalleled runout performance, authoring great accuracy. 
Beside the utility of the Tool, the low-sound, low-vibration soft-grip and aluminum housing offers maximum comfort with reduced operator fatigue. 
Another attractive feature in the work place to ease the professionals' task and enable more consistency throughout the day. These drills are specialty usual when performing important repair work on damaged aircraft, an application that must be repeatable and certainly critical in nature. We believe we have another industry winner. The PDx drilling is superior aviation tool consistent with the Snap-on name. 
Our Industrial division also has driven growth by leveraging a Snap-on RCI experience, participating in several customer-sponsored lean events right on the customer side. Side By side with the customers' local team. Snap-on people sharing their experiences and their insights with rapid continues improving, helping customers solve their problem -- but all the problems, but all the while aiming deeper, practical understanding of crucial tasks in critical industries, creating opportunities, tailor our products to the work and to drive more sales. We say we help professionals in solving the critical. RCI's becoming the tool to do just that. 
Our Asia/Pacific division also poses higher activity, registering progress, building the physicals and limiting the impact of the economic difficulties in Japan. I was just there attending our Annual Resellers conference, this year was in Xeon in China. Bringing together enthusiastic Snap-on associate and resellers from all across the region. New Asianized products were introduced, training seminars were conducted and the group's enthusiasm confirmed our extended opportunities in Asia/Pacific at C&I. 
Now on the Tools Group. Organic sales up 12.9%, solid growth in all geographies. The group's operating earnings of $59.8 million represented a margin rate of 15.8%, up 150 basis points. The Tools Group. The results continue to speak for themselves. They clearly demonstrate ongoing progress along one of our runways for coherent growth, enhancing the franchise channel. And there's abundant evidence of the strength of positive trajectory of that channel. It displayed clearly in our franchisee metrics, financial and physical. Important indicators of network help like sales per van and franchisee turnover. We monitor them closely and they're favorable across the board. 
Our direct interactions with the franchisees, meetings like the 2015 kickoffs held all over the network earlier in the year. They were marked by an -- I can tell you, they were marked by enthusiasm and optimism, by commitment and energy. Gatherings of entrepreneurs and professionals, confident in reaching higher. 
Snap-on Value Creation process, the processes. They're also critical importance of the Tools Group process. Innovative new products. Many, many of these launched from the customer connections we observed on a daily basis. Those solutions, those products are significant players in driving the group's upward trajectory. An example is the KR 1163 stools storage cap with the power tool organizer system. Based on customer connections made on a Rock 'N Roll express bands. These model transforms the bottom drawer, the box into a customizes secure, easy to access storage system for frequently used power tools. It's a feature that can make a technician's work easier. Visitors to our Rock 'N Roll cabs highlighted the need. Our design teams made it a reality. Customer connection, to innovation to winning products. 
Speaking of tool storage. This summer mark's our 95th year in business. And we just launched a special set up tool storage boxes, highlighting our long tradition of excellence with unique anniversary panels and custom-rich trim, etched with the years 1920 and 2015. 
New units also offered the Snap-on Atco remote locking system, another customer connection-driven option that we're confident will be quite popular. The special anniversary boxes are already gathering or generating considerable excitement on the van and in the shops. Lots of excitement around these box. And we believe they'll be strong sellers, clear testimony on the strength of the Snap-on brand and of the bond between Snap-on and professionals. 
More innovation can be seen in products like the new Snap-on half inch drive 36-inch breaker bar, the SHN 36. Originally developed from customer sections of the heavy-duty mechanics, desiring more -- a longer handle for increased leverage. The addition of the soft grip provides added control on comfort and that's a premium when you're removing tires or adjusting tracks on construction and agricultural equipment, or loosening head bolts on large engines. A much improved product will make work easier. Innovation even on the most established of product lines. 
Finally, I want to mention the Tools Group with RCI. It's clearly evident in the financials, but to double down on a testimony. I spoke before on our Annual RCI Conference where a team from Tools was awarded the grand champion at this year's event. The Tools Group rework center won for their work on substantially reducing turnaround time, highlighting that Snap-on. Shop floor has no monopoly on RCI and illustrating that even in and experienced organization like the Tools Group, potential RCI opportunities abound, up and down throughout and across the business. 
And we can't talk about the Tools Group without speaking of that strategic partner, our Financial Services organization. With each quarter, Snap-on Credit becomes more attuned to just what programs can best aid our franchisees, and the first quarter demonstrated that progress clearly. Portfolio growth, profits up over 17%. And all the while, holding delinquencies to a relatively low level. Snap-on Credit, the greatest historic tools business, and you can see that relationship play out in the positive trend. 
Now let's move to RS&I. The first quarter organic sales for RS&I rose 6.3%, forward games with both OEM dealerships and with independent shops. Operating earnings of $63.9 million were up $5.8 million. The operating margin of 23.5% rose 140 basis points. 
I've spoken often in the past about our line of successful handheld diagnostic units. As they continue to drive growth and excitement in independent repair space, the first quarter was no exception with our various Pro and modest Ultra units in recognized by Undercard Digest in this year's list of top 10 tools, continuing our strength of award-winning products with that publication. The Undercard Digest bases its selections on the votes of actual users. The award confirms that our handheld diagnostics strongly with professionals and it demonstrates the power of customer connection and innovation in generating unique productivity solution. That's what these tools are about. 
Various Pro and the -- they are also key components of our next-generation advanced diagnostic workstations. Launched in February, these new workstations include a handheld diagnostic unit and docking station, a flat screen monitor and a custom Snap-on toolbox. They provide comprehensive diagnostic support, fix scars accurately and quickly. And they go along way in reinforcing the shops' images, having strong professional capability in the electronics arena. A feature, we believe, have significant value to many independent garages as they strive to build customer confidence in this environment of rising vehicle technology. With more than 800 workstations sold since the launch, this is another one of our hit products, with over $1 million in first-year sales. And it's another edge to our growing track record of innovation success and its driving sales progress. 
Our equipment division also registered grains in the quarter was several national accounts, in part exceeding by highlighting our expanding product bundle, including Challenger Lifts, Pro-Cut on-car brake lace, as well as the new under car equipment and broad diagnostic offerings. Snap-on Equipment, increased productivity for the automotive repair shop -- for automotive repair shop networks, an advantage rooted in our expanded and enhanced line of products. 
Finally, we continue to see further progress with our next heavy-duty and fleet information systems, as well as progress with the improved functionality and comprehensive content contained in ProDemand and Sure track products, all are differentiated -- differentiating offerings that lead to more business. Armed with those products, we achieved a number of multilocation customer wins in the quarter, displacing competitors and gaining traction across the marketplace. Snap-on information products, unique database solutions, effective navigation systems for speed to repair, all emphasizing our growing strength and vehicle information and they help drive RS&I sales again this quarter. 
But that's the highlights. Significant progress was made in the quarter. Organic sales rising 9.9% along all our runways for coherent growth. EPS of $1.87, up 15.4%. Gains achieved through our Snap-on Value Creation Processes. RCI and customer connection shining -- especially shining through, strengthening our businesses and driving to a 16.7% opco operating margin, up 120 basis points. It was an encouraging quarter. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Aldo.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Nick. For our first quarter consolidated operating results are summarized on Slide 6. Net sales of $827.8 million in the quarter were up 9.9% organically, reflecting broad-based growth across all of our operating segments. On reported basis, net
componenttext:
Thanks, Nick. For our first quarter consolidated operating results are summarized on Slide 6. 
Net sales of $827.8 million in the quarter were up 9.9% organically, reflecting broad-based growth across all of our operating segments. On reported basis, net sales, including $38.5 million of unfavorable foreign currency translation, increased $40.3 million or 5.1% from 2014 levels. As you know, Snap-on has significant international operations and is subject to foreign currency translation fluctuations, largely due to this recent strengthening of the U.S. dollar, foreign currency movements adversely impacted our year-over-year sales comparisons by approximately 540 basis points. 
Consolidated gross profit of $410.1 million increased $31.4 million from 2014 levels. Gross margin of 49.5% in the quarter improved 140 basis points, primarily due to benefits from higher sales, lower restructuring costs and savings from RCI initiatives. 
Operating expenses of $272.2 million increased $15.2 million, largely due to higher volume-related and other expenses, partially offset by savings from RCI initiatives. The operating expense margin of 32.8% increased 20 basis points from 2014 levels. No restructuring costs were incurred in the first 3 months of 2015. 
Last year, we incurred $2 million of restructuring costs. 
Pension expense in the quarter was approximately $2 million higher as compared to the prior year, reflecting updated pension plan assumptions for 2015, which include the effects of lower discount rates, as well as increased life expectancies. As a result of these factors, operating earnings before Financial Services of $137.9 million in the quarter, including $6.4 million of unfavorable foreign currency effects, increased $16.2 million from prior-year levels as a percentage of sales improved 120 basis points to 16.7%. 
Financial Services revenue of $57.4 million in the quarter increased 14.3% from 2014 levels, while operating earnings of $40.3 million increased 17.2%. The increases in both revenue and operating earnings primarily reflect the continued growth of the Financial Services portfolio. 
Consolidated operating earnings of $178.2 million in the quarter, including $6.9 million of unfavorable foreign currency effects, increased $22.1 million or 14.2%. And the operating margin of 20.1% improved 150 basis points from 18.6% a year ago. Our first quarter effective income tax rate of 32% compared with 31.6% last year. 
Finally, net earnings of $110.5 million or $1.87 per diluted share increased $14.6 million or $0.25 per share, representing a 15.4% increase in diluted earnings per share. 
Now let's turn to our segment results. Starting with the Commercial & Industrial, or C&I Group, on Slide 7. Sales of $297.5 million in the quarter were up 9.8% organically, primarily reflecting similar sales strength, both in critical industries and in our European-based hand tools business. 
Gross profit for C&I Group totaled $116.5 million in the quarter and the gross margin of 39.2% improved 40 basis points from 2014 levels, largely due to savings from RCI initiatives, primarily in Europe. 
Operating expenses of $72.5 million in the quarter decreased $1.1 million. The operating expense margin of 24.4% improved 90 basis points, largely due to the sales volume leverage. As a result of these factors, operating earnings for the C&I segment of $44 million, including $1.3 million of unfavorable foreign currency effects, increased $4.9 million from 2014 levels. The operating margin of 14.8% improved 130 basis points. 
Turning now to Slide 8. First quarter sales on the Snap-on Tools Group of $378.2 million increased 12.9% organically, reflecting comparable sales gains in both the company's U.S. and international franchise operations. Gross profit of $166.3 million increased $18.3 million from 2014 levels and the gross margin of 44% improved 90 basis points, primarily due to benefits from higher sales. 
Operating expenses of $106.5 million increased $7.7 million from 2014 levels, mostly due to higher volume-related expenses. The operating expense margin of 28.2% improved 60 basis points, principally due to sales volume leverage. As a result of these factors, operating earnings for the Snap-on Tools Group of $59.8 million, including $3 million of unfavorable foreign currency effects, increased $10.6 million in the operating margin of 15.8% improved 150 basis points. 
Turning to the repair, systems and information, RS&I Group showed on Slide 9. Sales of $272.3 million in the quarter increased 6.3% organically from 2014 levels. The organic sales increase primarily reflects a high single-digit gain in sales of undercar equipment, as well as mid-single digit gains in both sales to OEM dealerships and the sales of diagnostic and repair information products to independent repair shop owners and managers.
Gross profit of $127.3 million increased $9.3 million over 2014 levels. And gross margin of 46.8% improved 190 basis points, principally due to savings from RCI and other cost reduction initiatives and $2 million of lower restructuring cost.  Operating expenses totaled $63.4 million in the quarter. The operating expense margin of 23.3% increased 50 basis points, largely due to operating expenses of Pro-Cut, which was acquired in May of last year. 
First quarter operating earnings for the RS&I Group of $63.9 million, including $2.1 million of unfavorable foreign currency effects, increased $5.8 million or 10% from prior-year levels. And the operating margin of 23.5% improved 140 basis points. 
Now turning to Slide 10. In the first quarter, operating earnings from Financial Services of $40.3 million and revenue of $57.4 million, with operating earnings of $34.4 million and revenue of $50.2 million last year. The average yield on finance receivables of 17.7% in the quarter compared with 17.5% last year. The average yield on contract receivables was 9.5% in both periods. Originations of $230.7 million increased 14.2% from 2014 levels.
Moving to Slide 11. As of quarter-end, our balance sheet includes approximately $1.4 billion of gross financing receivables, including $1.2 billion from our U.S. Snap-on credit operation. Approximately 80% of our U.S. financing portfolio relates to extended credit loans to technicians. During the quarter, our worldwide finance portfolio grew approximately $23 million.  As for finance portfolio losses and delinquency trends, these continue to be in line with our expectations. 
Now turning to Slide 12. Cash provided by operations of $78.1 million in the quarter decreased $10.2 million from comparable 2014 levels as higher net earnings in 2015 were more than offset by net increases in operating assets and liabilities, largely as a result of a $15 million discretionary domestic pension plan contribution, as well as higher tax-related payments in the current year. 
Net cash used by investing activities of $59.5 million included $38.6 million to fund a net increase in finance receivables. 
Capital expenditures of $18.1 million in the quarter were comparable to the prior year.
Turning to Slide 13. Days sales outstanding for trade receivables of 60 days compared with 61 days at 2014 year end. Inventories increased 6.8 million from 2014 year end levels, primarily to support continued higher customer demand and new product introductions. On a trailing 12-month basis, inventory turns of 3.6 compared with 3.7 turns at 2014 year end. At quarter end, cash position of $114.4 million decreased $18.5 million from 2014 year end levels. Net decrease includes the impact of funding $198.8 million of new finance receivables, the repurchase of 340,000 shares for $49.7 million, dividend payments of $30.9 million in capital expenditures of $18.1 million. These cash decreases were partially offset by $160.2 million of cash from collections of finance receivables, $78.1 million of cash generated from operations and $22.8 million of cash from a net increase in short-term borrowings. Our net debt-to-cap ratio of 27.6% compared with 26.3% at 2014 year-end. 
In addition to our $114 million of cash and expected cash flow from operations, we have more than $700 million in available credit facilities, and our current short-term credit ratings allow us to access commercial paper markets. At first quarter end, we had $52.5 million of commercial paper borrowings outstanding. 
This concludes my remarks on our first quarter performance. Now I'll turn the call over to Nick for his closing thoughts. Nick?

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Aldo. Now as our first quarter similar to our other quarters, growth and improvement. EPS of $1.87, up 15.4%. Once again, there were headwinds, varying economies, fluctuating currencies and political unrest, but we overcame by finding and making t
componenttext:
Thanks, Aldo. Now as our first quarter similar to our other quarters, growth and improvement. EPS of $1.87, up 15.4%. Once again, there were headwinds, varying economies, fluctuating currencies and political unrest, but we overcame by finding and making the most other opportunities. We've made significant progress along our runways for growth, driven by new products and new customers. Enhanced the Van channel. Tools Group organic sales up 12.9%, and we believe the network has never been stronger. Expand with repair shop owners and managers. RS&I organic sales up 6.3%. OEM, dealerships and independent shops capturing new customers with a growing product bundle, extent critical industries and build and emerging market. 
C&I organic sales up 9.8%. Europe progressing against the equal tied. Our critical industry team building our understanding of those critical workplaces, launching new products aimed at those tasks and gaining position. Once again, again this quarter, we clearly saw the effects of Snap-on Value Creation, advancing down our runway for improvement. OI margin improvements are more than 100 basis points in every group. And an overall opco margin of 16.7%, an increase of 120 basis points. It was an encouraging quarter. We believe it serves as more testimony, great testimony. That our business models have the strength, our runways offer the opportunity and our teams have the capability to continue this trend positive progress as we move forward even amid headwind. 
Before I turn the call over to the operator, it's appropriate that I mention our franchisees and associates. I know many of you are listening today. Encouraging performance of the first quarter and the positive trends are continuing due to your contribution and commitments. For the results you've offered -- authored, for the results you've authored, you have my congratulations. And for your dedication and support to our team, you have my thanks. 
Now I'll turn the call over to the operator. Operator?

componenttext: I'm just wondering, specifically on the C&I Group, great organic growth. I was just wondering if very any industries that maybe outperformed your expectations? And then early to that, I'm just wondering about your exposure on oil and gas market and have some challenges right now?

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, look. I expect good news in every market every quarter, I think, because we're not -- the thing is we're in early days in penetrating critical industries. It's an aspect of coherent growth that what we are doing there is duplicating what we have done
componenttext: Yes, look. I expect good news in every market every quarter, I think, because we're not -- the thing is we're in early days in penetrating critical industries. It's an aspect of coherent growth that what we are doing there is duplicating what we have done for automotive repair technicians all these years. We're doing them for other people in other industries, observing work and making it easier with just just the right tools, whether it's software or hardware. And so an element of that is learning about the industry. So it's early days. Now we have very industries in there, aviation, the military, oil and gas, power generation, mining. One of the advantages of this is we don't really have in the way of share in these businesses, so therefore, each quarter rise and fall is not so much on the effect of the industry, just on our own performance. So we have lumpiness from section to section or from industry to industry. In this particular quarter, we actually saw fine performance in places, like I said, in my power generation, mining, railroads, the military. The military was at this time, because we were able to see opportunities. Aviation is a big business in that area and oil and gas actually, actually was up even slightly in this quarter. So we saw the usual lumpiness from operation to operation but the critical industries business is really is the driver behind C&I. You see the C&I growth across those segments. So I didn't see any particular surprises. I guess if you are looking at our business, you might say gee, they grew in oil and gas even though the market was weak. My view was we don't have that big a share in oil and gas, therefore, we can grow against the markets.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: The organic growth on the Snap-on Tool segment is pretty strong, closer to the high-single digits.  A lot higher than more of a mid-single digit expectation. What's driving that incremental growth?
componenttext: The organic growth on the Snap-on Tool segment is pretty strong, closer to the high-single digits.  A lot higher than more of a mid-single digit expectation. What's driving that incremental growth?

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think what's driving it is, is that the Tools Group team is understanding how to enable the franchisees that we have in various places. We have 4,800 worldwide. We have 3,478 I think in the United States. And they're learning quarter-by-quarter, h
componenttext: Well, I think what's driving it is, is that the Tools Group team is understanding how to enable the franchisees that we have in various places. We have 4,800 worldwide. We have 3,478 I think in the United States. And they're learning quarter-by-quarter, how to do it better. And that's allowance itself more same customers and reach other customers, which they had on the routes, but they haven't been calling on. So the effects are these, I think. Maybe threefold. 1 effect is I think constructed many times. I think there. They're really breaking to the natural boundaries of that model by adding space with the Rock 'N Roll cabs, and you can see on the progression of the tool storage and breaking through the time by adding help with things like the TechKnow vans. Now I think we have 66, 67 Rock 'N Roll -- 66 Rock 'N Roll Van throughout the world now. And we have now up to 35 TechKnow Van, up about 4 since last quarter. And so you can see breaking that national boundary is helping. Secondly, boy, we're using as much as possible our customer connection. We spend a lot of time in the shops, and we are organizing that process in getting that information back into the innovation process and rolling out new products like that 36-inch breaker bar. People might look at that and say, what's that? It's just a long bar. But the idea was it wasn't really available in the marketplace and the ones that were available aren't as comfortable. Innovation doesn't have to be earth shattering, it just have to make work easier in the space in the tools [indiscernible] how to do that. And then thirdly, they're looking at the franchisees and saying, we know your time is valuable. We're going to make it better. We're going to drive our RCI into the van, and that's what's resulting these kinds of thing. The numbers were up 12.8% in the quarter -- 12.9% in the quarter. 11.8% the quarter before that, 6% the quarter before that, 6.6% the quarter before that and 6 before that. In fact, 19 of the last 20 quarters, they've been 6% or above. And that's -- what's driving at all is tuning that business. It's kind of -- if step back and you look at the auto repair business, you'll say it's going to go better than GDP. 4% to 6% is with we say. But if you have capability that resonates with those franchisees like they figured out, you see these kind of numbers.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And you touched on RCI across all businesses. They were providing incremental profitability, along with volume increases. Can you push RCI in a similar fashion as the van channel?
componenttext: Okay. And you touched on RCI across all businesses. They were providing incremental profitability, along with volume increases. Can you push RCI in a similar fashion as the van channel?

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. That's what we're doing. We're putting RCI into the van drivers. Things like, I think I've mentioned this before, but things like when you repair a ratchet. Repairing a ratchet was taking 15 minutes, every ratchet. Sometimes I was on van when people
componenttext: Sure. That's what we're doing. We're putting RCI into the van drivers. Things like, I think I've mentioned this before, but things like when you repair a ratchet. Repairing a ratchet was taking 15 minutes, every ratchet. Sometimes I was on van when people brought 4 different ratchets, 4 ratchets one stop that would've killed the route that day, but we have tools. Kind of just like a factory, you laying it out like a factory. Like our van drivers can repair it in 3 or 4 minutes now. And number of things like that. So taking RCI, looking at the van, doing value stream mapping on the van and reducing the time, adding to the selling time is part of the process, which is allowing them to reach out to more customers. That's exactly what we've been doing. Thanks for that question.

componenttext: I don't think so. I think not any particular product. I don't think -- I'm sure I could go through our launching of new products and find those that came from a company-owned store driver. In fact -- but only around customer connection. We have the Van driver ourselves. The guys an employee, he goes out there and reports. He gives us leads for new tools as part of the company-owned, stores. And that falls back. But we don't really differentiate between elite from the company-owned stores and the franchisee. But in my remarks, you might've heard the whole idea of the power tool drawer organizer at the bottom at the tool storage box. That came from the Rock 'N Roll cab. We have these -- and their company stores. They're not selling, but their company stores are rolling there. People Rock 'N Roll cabs and they started talking about boy, would be cool if we have the power to organizer in one of the stores. We got that idea, we give it to the engineers. They put in place and we're rolling out this new product and it's looking to be a good seller. So that's an example. I think the only thing if you have company-owned stores, they just add to the flow of ideas back in the field. The customer connection the comes back to the field.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I guess my question was more oriented towards the Rock 'N Roll cab and the TechKnow Van put really a spotlight on particular things. Is there some extension of that strategy that you can keep rolling out across the Tools Group?
componenttext: So I guess my question was more oriented towards the Rock 'N Roll cab and the TechKnow Van put really a spotlight on particular things. Is there some extension of that strategy that you can keep rolling out across the Tools Group?

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we only have -- we have 35 TechKnow vans now. We actually added a couple Rock 'N Roll cabs in the last quarter, so that's growing much more slowly. But we added 4 TechKnow vans, so but they may continue to grow some. Whether we add another extension
componenttext: Well, we only have -- we have 35 TechKnow vans now. We actually added a couple Rock 'N Roll cabs in the last quarter, so that's growing much more slowly. But we added 4 TechKnow vans, so but they may continue to grow some. Whether we add another extension, we may have some ideas, but I don't think I'm going to preannounce them on the call here. I think that's the magic of the magicians, is try to find out more techniques and activities or programs that would expand the power of the franchisees. See, I think one of the things I just want to point out. Part of really what the Tools Group has done is they figured out that these vans, these franchisees are a great resource. They're better than anybody else's and they figured out how to help them be more powerful and amplify that power of that rolling retail space and that really capable and committed entrepreneur that's driving it. And we're going to do more of that, but I'm not about to announce any more of that.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. And then switching gears over to the profitability in RS&I this quarter. You called out a few product areas and I would normally think are a bit lower margin within that segment, yet the margins improved year-over-year. Has RCI kind of neutra
componenttext: Fair enough. And then switching gears over to the profitability in RS&I this quarter. You called out a few product areas and I would normally think are a bit lower margin within that segment, yet the margins improved year-over-year. Has RCI kind of neutralized thinking about that business in terms of software being sold or equipment being sold from any EBIT margin standpoint?

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: As I've said many times on these calls, RS&I is the hardest to characterize from a margin perspective. Yes, we had good growth and things like equipment, which tends to be lower margin, but we had a good quarter in software. I said it. Our software is rol
componenttext: As I've said many times on these calls, RS&I is the hardest to characterize from a margin perspective. Yes, we had good growth and things like equipment, which tends to be lower margin, but we had a good quarter in software. I said it. Our software is rolling. When I go out and talk to people, they love our diagnostics. In many cases, they're solving problems 3 or 4x faster than anybody else, 3 or 4x faster than anybody else and the software is up. So that's good stuff. Our Mitchell 1 information business on our diagnostics and the independent garage are pretty robust. And yes, Okay, equipments growing, but those 2 things are relatively in balance. So I don't think we saw a lot of mix in those numbers except for maybe the acquisition, might thing that a little bit. Now the story of 140 basis points in, I think it's 140 basis points in RS&I is we had about 50 60 of -- or about 15 60 of RCI and we had 70 or 80 of restructuring because last year, we had a big restructuring dollop in there. But that's why you can't count vaguely we look at that, but still a pretty big dollop of RCI. Of course, you want to make them stick about this. Even though the equipment, the lower margin businesses are growing solely to software.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: The inevitable question on margins. And just looking at the gross margin, I think that gross margin review reported in Q1 was probably at the highest that it's been for quite some time. And I was just wondering if there was something in there that gotten above 49% or one time deal? Or are we at a new kind of sustainable level here? If you can directly talk about that?

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, look, I don't -- we don't spend a lot of time agonizing over the difference between gross margin and OE. I kind of test the operations to drive their operating income, and I tend to focus on that much more. And what we've said is, is that we believe
componenttext: Yes, look, I don't -- we don't spend a lot of time agonizing over the difference between gross margin and OE. I kind of test the operations to drive their operating income, and I tend to focus on that much more. And what we've said is, is that we believe that we have both runways for growth and improvement that accrued operating income. And from quarter to quarter,  the accrue those things accrued in different proportions between gross margin and operating expense. So I wouldn't call gross margin is fairly breakthrough, but there's nothing special in there this quarter. There's nothing really -- there's no real -- I don't think there's any real onetime event or anything like that. Really, I mean, you saw our currency numbers in the quarter. I think our sales were -- what was it, 38.5% in currency and about 6.9% in OI. We're -- we have currency headwinds and if the current rates basis, those will rise. But on the other hand, we believe that, that's sort of arithmetic. We've stolen about our operating opportunities, and you can see it in this quarter. The operating opportunities worked up. Currencies are going to go up and down, but the operating gains are going to stay with us forever, and we view the 16.7% being part of that.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's fair. And then Europe. I've been reading that new car registrations are up. It seems that you're starting to get some traction, and I think you said European hand tools business top line was up commensurate with C&I. So the cases been you've
componenttext: Okay, that's fair. And then Europe. I've been reading that new car registrations are up. It seems that you're starting to get some traction, and I think you said European hand tools business top line was up commensurate with C&I. So the cases been you've moved on a quarterly basis over the last couple of quarters from low-single digit to mid-single digits to high-single digits growth in...

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: It hasn't been that -- I don't think it's been that -- thinking about it back, I have to go back and look at it, but I don't think it's been that sort of straight line. But if you look at it over like 8 quarters or something like that, you probably see so
componenttext: It hasn't been that -- I don't think it's been that -- thinking about it back, I have to go back and look at it, but I don't think it's been that sort of straight line. But if you look at it over like 8 quarters or something like that, you probably see some kind of movement. I think what happened this quarter is basically some of our activities are paying off associated with new product development. We do have some new product that are exciting the customers. You can create enthusiasm even in what I consider to be a relatively dead market in Europe. New car sales [indiscernible] help us that much except for the fact that -- except for the broader fact that new car sales are probably accompanying a more positive economy. It is true though that we made I think encouraging gains in selling in Europe. France and Germany, which had been a drag in the last couple of quarters, in fact, they were down at the last couple of quarters. They were up this quarter and we continued with the Nordic countries, and we had some business in Turkey. Of course, Eastern Europe was weak. So -- and Spain was up off of a relatively slow pace. So we kind of saw the same progress in Europe that we've seen in other quarters, except we started making progress in France and Germany. Eastern Europe is kind of dead right now and it's difficult, and so on. But it's kind of, I guess, you could be entitled to the Europe got somewhat better. But profits were even better, very strong performance because of the effects of RCI.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's great news. And then lastly, just look at this -- the reported revenues and the unfavorable currency translation. If I add back the impact of currency translation and then say you have about 25% of your sales are based internationally, is that corr
componenttext: That's great news. And then lastly, just look at this -- the reported revenues and the unfavorable currency translation. If I add back the impact of currency translation and then say you have about 25% of your sales are based internationally, is that correct?

I was just wondering whether was the euro down that much that it caused that kind of drag on the numbers? Or is my math wrong?

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: The euro was down. We have several currencies that impact this on a translation basis. You've got -- first of all, you've got the euro, and then you've got the pound and then you get the Canadian dollar. So I'll say look at that. Actually, when I said 35%
componenttext: The euro was down. We have several currencies that impact this on a translation basis. You've got -- first of all, you've got the euro, and then you've got the pound and then you get the Canadian dollar. So I'll say look at that. Actually, when I said 35%, I was embracing our northern neighbors here and I was using Canada. If you just look at the United States, if you think of Canada as international, which is somehow I don't really always, it's 40% outside the United States. Canada is in there. So you see those kind of variations. I mean, basically, one of those companies that is current -- we are affected by currency, but we have some good -- some regional from transactions because we tend to make in markets where we sell.

componenttextpreview: No, not in everything. We're not immune. Sort of like this, we're currency resistant from a transaction point of view, but we're not immune. So we don't wring our hands over it. We see it coming. Like I said clearly, we had currency last year actually. We
componenttext: No, not in everything. We're not immune. Sort of like this, we're currency resistant from a transaction point of view, but we're not immune. So we don't wring our hands over it. We see it coming. Like I said clearly, we had currency last year actually. We've got it this year. If the rates stay where they are, rise some. But it doesn't effect our operating activity because we know that this 16.7% is going to stay with us, that 12.9% is going to stay with us, that night 9.8% is going to stay with us.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was looking at the currency impact a little bit differently. I added back the currency impacts to each one of the revenues for each of the groups and then also added back the negative impact for currency for each one of their operating results. The year
componenttext: I was looking at the currency impact a little bit differently. I added back the currency impacts to each one of the revenues for each of the groups and then also added back the negative impact for currency for each one of their operating results. The year-over-year increase or expansion in margin excluding currency, was 140 basis points. When I did all of those add backs, I came up with an expansion that was just about 10 basis points less than that at about 130, which is still fantastic performance. But I'm curious, is that because -- and correct me if I'm wrong, but isn't C&I a little bit more of the mix when you add back the currencies and that's why the expansion wasn't quite as much when you take into consideration the currency?

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't know. I'll tell you this, I'll tell you this. Is that in our numbers, 120 basis points for our calculation, no effect of currency in that 120. Now as it all balances out at the corporate level, at the corporate level, it all balances out. So we do
componenttext: I don't know. I'll tell you this, I'll tell you this. Is that in our numbers, 120 basis points for our calculation, no effect of currency in that 120. Now as it all balances out at the corporate level, at the corporate level, it all balances out. So we don't really -- at a margin level, at a margin rate level. So the 16.7% from our perspective is basically all RCI. It's pretty much -- it's got bad news form pension. It's got bad news from pension, and so on, and it's primarily RCI in volume productivity.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: Yes, no matter how you slice it, it's still a good performance.

componenttext: It's got a little bit restructuring good news offsetting pension and the rest is productivity currency doesn't come in there.  But if you go by the various groups, C&I has helped a little bit. On a margin rate basis, not on an absolute basis, by currency, tools Group being Tools Group. If they didn't have currency, Tools Group will be much more -- it would have been more than 150 basis points and RCI, a little bit of currency. So that's the way it kind of works out.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the hand tools side. Since we've had improving economic conditions for the last 3, 4 years now, is this -- have you seen an increase in the number of garages opening up in the United States? Does that also help?
componenttext: Okay. And then on the hand tools side. Since we've had improving economic conditions for the last 3, 4 years now, is this -- have you seen an increase in the number of garages opening up in the United States? Does that also help?

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, technicians -- the technician population is probably growing at about 1.3% for government work, that will be the number. But the garages, in fact, if anything, actually, depending on how far back you go, the dealerships have shrunk. I think the dealer
componenttext: No, technicians -- the technician population is probably growing at about 1.3% for government work, that will be the number. But the garages, in fact, if anything, actually, depending on how far back you go, the dealerships have shrunk. I think the dealerships were about 21,000 before recession. Now they're at 17,000, or 18 -- between 17,000 and 18,000. So they shrunk. The independent have stayed about the same, the independence have taken more share. That started before the recession. That seems to maybe -- this date always trail, so that's kind of leveled off, a lot of people think now. But I think there hasn't been a big change in the characteristics, except independence are becoming more sophisticated because they have to deal with the changing technologies. 20 years ago, there were 50 engine codes on a car now despite 1,000 engine codes. It's hard to fix a car without a diagnostic unit now, and we have the best one. And so we're selling them to technicians now, not just the garages. That's helping drive our business. So the technology change in the independent space that's why I talked about the diagnostic workstations. Because the independent garages know that people know their cars are more like spaceships these days, and they want to bring them to people who can fix them. And therefore, this diagnostic unit makes it look like wow, this is the computer here that can fix the car, help fix the car and boasts confidence. And actually helps general in terms of accuracy. So if anything, we're seeing a greater demand by products in independent shops and other shops because of the changing technology. That's the big change.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then with respect to your comments about Europe and new car sales and what that means in terms of hand tools sales over there, just noticing Western Europe trailing 12 months, new car sales are up about 6%. Eastern Europe, however though
componenttext: Okay, great. And then with respect to your comments about Europe and new car sales and what that means in terms of hand tools sales over there, just noticing Western Europe trailing 12 months, new car sales are up about 6%. Eastern Europe, however though is up about 10%. They were up as much as 15% back about around the third quarter, so last year, but that growth rate has kind of steadily gone down a bit. They're still tracking year-over-year increases. So I'm kind of curious. It make sense that France and Germany, you're doing better. The industry is doing better in general in those 2 countries, but I'm surprised that Eastern Europe hasn't really kept up with the expansion of the new car demand. Any comments about that?

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: You have a new car demands down in Eastern Europe, right? I mean new car 50. But for us, new cars don't matter. I mean I think I said that. Because the new car sales are almost always, except in emerging markets, place like China and India, and so on they
componenttext: You have a new car demands down in Eastern Europe, right? I mean new car 50. But for us, new cars don't matter. I mean I think I said that. Because the new car sales are almost always, except in emerging markets, place like China and India, and so on they're almost always small compared to the installed base to the car park. Consider the U.S., $16 million cars, 16 -- North America, what, 17 million, 18 million cars sold. There's are 300 million on the road. It's like fly speck almost, the new cars, compared to those other roads. So it doesn't really move our business that much up and down in sort of a short wave basis. In terms of Eastern Europe, I think I would just suggest to you that I'm not really sure what's going on in Eastern Europe. It's a cocktail of different countries, so it's really hard to say. I mean, you saw Russia being so weak. On the other hand, our business is up in Poland, for example, if you include that in Eastern Europe. It's hard to make much prediction about that. I think this is just one of those turbulent things that where traditional economics don't always work in every period.

componenttext: Sure. Sure, but that's a longer wave event. In other words, you're right, Richard. But the next year isn't that much different. It changes some, and so people need to adjust for that. But these things work through over time. I was reacting to the idea that people say well, new car sales are up in the first quarter, therefore, your business is going to be better. I don't think so. It doesn't affect us that much for much longer [indiscernible] .

So over time, it will mirror that. And I think if you look back, it's rather consistent with the Tools Group performance over the last several quarters.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
