componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Snap-on Incorporated 2015 First Quarter Results Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Leslie Kratcoski, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jamie, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us today to review Snap-on's first quarter results, which are detailed in our press release issued earlier this morning. We have on the call today Nick Pinchuk, Snap-on's Chief Executive Offi
componenttext:
Thanks, Jamie, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us today to review Snap-on's first quarter results, which are detailed in our press release issued earlier this morning. 
We have on the call today Nick Pinchuk, Snap-on's Chief Executive Officer; and Aldo Pagliari, Snap-on's Chief Financial Officer. Nick will kick off our call this morning with his perspective on our performance. Aldo will then provide a more detailed review of our financial results. After Nick provides some closing thoughts, we'll take your questions. 
As usual, we've provided slides to supplement our discussion. You can find a copy of these slides on our website next to the audio icon for the call. These slides will be archived on our website, along with the transcript. 
Any statements made during this call relative to management's expectations, estimates or beliefs or otherwise state management's or the company's outlook, plans or projections are forward-looking statements, and actual results may differ materially from those made in such statements. Additional information and the factors that could cause our results to differ materially from those in the forward-looking statements are contained in our SEC filings. 
With that said, I'd now like to turn the call over to Nick Pinchuk. Nick?

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Leslie. Good morning, everyone. As usual, I'll start with the highlights of our first quarter. And along the way, I'll give you perspective on our results, our markets and on the progress we've made, and Aldo will move into a more detailed review
componenttext:
Thanks, Leslie. Good morning, everyone. As usual, I'll start with the highlights of our first quarter. And along the way, I'll give you perspective on our results, our markets and on the progress we've made, and Aldo will move into a more detailed review of the financials. 
I believe that our first quarter, once again, provided strong evidence of Snap-on advancing along our runways for both growth and for improvement. Our EPS in the quarter was $1.87, up from $1.62 last year. That rise reflects an opco operating margin of 16.7%, an increase of 120 basis points. Combining those opco gains with earnings of $40.3 million from Financial Services brought Snap-on's consolidated operating margin to 20.1% compared to the 18.6% registered last year. Our operating improvement in the quarter came on organic sales growth of 9.9%. Overall sales in the quarter were $827.8 million, a rise of 5.1% from the prior year, and those gains included significant unfavorable foreign currency translation of $38.5 million or 540 basis points. 
Now currency is a headwind. It was last year. It's likely to continue throughout the year. And if the present rates hold, it will rise somewhat going forward. But we are very encouraged by our organic growth in both volume and profitability, and we believe both represent a continuation of our strengthening position and capability and of the generally favorable business environment for each of our operating groups. For us, the quarter's results are testimony to the abundant opportunity along our runways for growth and our -- and of our ability to take advantage as conditions unfold. 
Like in past quarters, the environment surrounding our automotive repair-related businesses, the Tools Group and the RS&I group, is generally positive. The changing technologies across the fleet continue to drive the need for new problem-solving products, making those markets robust. In that regard, Tools Group have enhanced our franchise network with vans productivity and with innovative marketing, taking clear advantage of the favorability to sell more to existing customers and to reach new customers, all on its way to strong growth. At the same time, RS&I has also grown, capitalizing on those positives and utilizing its broader product line to expand with repair shop owners and managers. 
Now C&I, serving customers in critical industries and the most international of our groups, does face more variations in the market. European operations are confronted with large differences across the business, from the relatively calm U.K. to the turbulence of the Middle East, to the challenges of Russia, to the political uncertainties of newly elected governments in places like India and Indonesia. But as in past quarters, the opportunities outweigh those headwinds. And when combined with our growing range of customer-driven products and with our expanding capabilities aimed specifically at the needs of industries and customers, C&I again showed gains, extending in critical industries and building in emerging markets. 
Besides advancements on our runways for growth, we also made progress down our runways for improvement with Snap-on Value Creation in safety, quality, customer connection, innovation and rapid continuous improvement, or RCI as we call it. RCI has become a part of the fabric of daily activity at Snap-on. You can see it in the results, OI margins up. And you can see it in events like our annual RCI conference held recently just down the road in Illinois, nearly 400 people, almost 40 best practice teams came together to share ideas, vie for awards and celebrate their progress, bringing the learning and the enthusiasm back home to their local teams. You can't help but walk away from these events encouraged and convinced that there's great potential for further improvement. 
Last, the environment. Of course, as always, there are headwinds, market-to-market variations and difficult macros. But despite the challenges, our operations moved significantly along each of our runways for both growth and improvement and you can see it throughout the numbers. 
Now let's move to the segments. In C&I Group, organic sales were up 9.8%, with contributions coming from our European, U.S. and Asian operations. From an earnings perspective, C&I operating income of $44 million increased $4.9 million or 12.5%, and that represents a margin rate for C&I, up 14.8%, an expansion of 130 basis points. 
SNA Europe again recorded volume growth. This time, similar to that achieved by C&I overall, broad gains in many of our markets led by selling strength and by products that generate real enthusiasm. But SNA Europe's improvement in the quarter goes beyond sales growth and farther than the gains made from past restructuring. Our initiatives to improve productivity with focus on both cost and product development are clearly evident in the operations achievements. You can see it again this quarter. Organic sales were up. The profits, profits were up more, illustrating the power of RCI even in the European environment that remains challenged. 
Industrial division was also part of C&I rise. It grew in a number of critical industries, areas like power generation, mining, railroads and the military. As everybody knows, the military sector remains uncertain. But having said that, we've made the most of the opportunities available. This time, the opening arose with the changing roles of various units as the troops were redeployed back to the United States. Actually, that's a major theme for our first quarter, making the most of the opportunities as they arise amid the turbulence. 
Another big factor in the gains in critical industry were expanded product offerings targeted at practical workplace needs. One is -- one new example introduced in the quarter was the PDX (sic) [PDR] series of air drills, ideal for the aviation industry, made in our Murphy, North Carolina plant. And these pneumatic drills are used in application ranging from light assembly to metalworking, perfect for drilling ferrous and nonferrous metals, plastics and composite materials, the kind of versatility that's so helpful in aviation applications. And the featherable trigger provides outstanding control and unparalleled run-out performance, authoring great accuracy. Beside the utility of the tool, the low-sound, low-vibration, soft-grip and aluminum housing offers maximum comfort with reduced operator fatigue, another attractive feature in the work place to ease the professional's task and enable more consistency throughout the day. These drills are especially useful on performing important repair work on damaged aircraft steel, an application that must be repeatable and certainly critical in nature. We believe we have another industry winner. The PDX (sic) [PDR] drill, a superior aviation tool consistent with the Snap-on name. 
Our Industrial division also has driven growth by leveraging the Snap-on RCI experience, participating in several customer-sponsored lean events right on the customer site, side by side with the customer's local team. Snap-on people sharing their experiences and their insight of rapid continuous improving, helping customers solve their problem, but -- all the problems, but all the while aiming deeper, practical understanding of the -- of crucial tasks in critical industries, creating opportunities to tailor our products to the work and to drive more sales. We say we help professionals in solving the critical. RCI is becoming a tool to do just that. 
Our Asia Pacific division also posts a higher activity, registering progress, building the physicals and limiting the impact of the economic difficulties in Japan. I was just there attending our annual resellers conference this year within Xi'an in China, bringing together enthusiastic Snap-on associates and resellers from all across the region. New Asian-ized products were introduced, training seminars were conducted and the group's enthusiasm confirmed our extended opportunities in Asia Pacific at C&I. 
Now on to the Tools Group. Organic sales up 12.9%, solid growth in all geographies. The group's operating earnings of $59.8 million represented a margin rate of 15.8%, up 150 basis points, the Tools Group. The results continue to speak for themselves. They clearly demonstrate ongoing progress along one of our runways for coherent growth, enhancing the franchise channel. And there's abundant evidence of the strength of positive trajectory of that channel. It's displayed clearly in our franchisee metrics, financial and physical, important indicators of network help like sales per van and franchisee turnover. We monitor them closely, and they're favorable across-the-board. And our direct interactions with the franchisees, meetings like the 2015 kickoffs held all over the network earlier in the year, they were marked by -- I can tell you, they were marked by enthusiasm and optimism, by commitment and energy, gatherings of entrepreneurs and professionals confident in reaching higher. 
Snap-on Value Creation process, the processes, they're also critical components of the Tools Group progress. Innovative new products, many, many of these launched from the customer connections we observed on a daily basis. Those solutions, those products are significant players in driving the group's upward trajectory. An example is the KRL1163 tool storage cab with the power tool organizer system based on customer connections made on our Rock 'N Roll express vans. This model transforms the bottom drawer, the box, into a customized secure, easy-to-access storage system for frequently used power tools. It's a feature that can make a technician's work easier. Visitors to our Rock 'N Roll cabs highlighted the need, our design teams made it a reality, customer connection to innovation to winning products. 
Speaking of tool storage, this summer mark's our 95th year in business. And we just launched a special set of tool storage boxes, highlighting our long tradition of excellence with unique anniversary panel and custom-rich trim, etched with the years 1920 and 2015. The new units also offered the Snap-on echo remote locking system, another customer connection-driven option that we're confident will be quite popular. The specialty -- special anniversary boxes are already gathering -- generating considerable excitement on the vans and in the shops, lots of excitement around these boxes. And we believe they'll be strong sellers, clear testimony on the strength of the Snap-on brand and of the bond between Snap-on and professionals. 
More innovation can be seen in products like the new Snap-on 1/2-inch Drive 36-inch Breaker Bar, the SHN36 (sic) [SN36], originally developed from customer connections of the heavy-duty mechanics desiring more -- a longer handle for increased leverage. The addition of a soft grip provides added control on comfort and that's a premium when you're removing tires or adjusting tracks on construction and agricultural equipment or loosening head bolts on large engine. A much improved product will make work easier, innovation even on the most established of product lines. 
Finally, I want to mention the Tools Group efforts with RCI. Progress -- I think it's clearly evident in the financials. But to double down on a testimony -- I spoke before on our Annual RCI Conference. Well, a team from Tools was awarded the grand champion at this year's event. The Tools Group rework center won for their work on substantially reducing turnaround time, highlighting that Snap-on shop floor has no monopoly on RCI and illustrating that even in an -- even an experienced organization like the Tools Group, potential RCI opportunities abound, up and down throughout and across the business. 
And we can't talk about the Tools Group without speaking of its strategic partner, our Financial Services organization. With each quarter, Snap-on Credit becomes more attuned to just what programs can best aid our franchisees. And the first quarter demonstrated that progress clearly, portfolio growth, profits up over 17% and, all the while, holding delinquencies to a relatively low level. Snap-on Credit, a great assist to our Tools business, and you can see that relationship play out in the positive trends. 
Now let's move to RS&I. The first quarter organic sales for RS&I rose 6.3%, broad gains with both OEM dealerships and with independent shops. Operating earnings of $63.9 million were up $5.8 million. The operating margin of 23.5% rose 140 basis points. 
I've spoken often in the past about our line of successful handheld diagnostic units. As they continue to drive growth and excitement in the independent repair space, the first quarter was no exception with our VERUS PRO and MODIS Ultra units being recognized by Undercar Digest in this year's list of top 10 tools, continuing our strength of award-winning products with that publication. The Undercar Digest bases its selections on the votes of actual users. The award confirms that our handheld diagnostics resonate strongly with professionals, and it demonstrates the power of customer connection and innovation in generating unique productivity solutions. That's what these tools are about. 
VERUS PRO and the MODIS Ultra, they're also key components of our next-generation advanced diagnostic workstations. Launched in February, these new workstations include a handheld diagnostic unit and docking station, a flat screen monitor and a custom Snap-on toolbox. They provide comprehensive diagnostic support to fix cars accurately and quickly, and they go a long way in reinforcing the shops' images, having strong professional capability in the electronics arena, a feature, we believe, is of significant value to many independent garages as they strive to build customer confidence in this environment of rising vehicle technology. With more than 800 workstations sold since the launch, this is another one of our hit products with over $1 million in the -- in first-year sales. And it's another add to our growing track record of innovation success and its driving sales progress. 
Our equipment division also registered gains in the quarter with several national accounts, in part exceeding by highlighting our expanding product bundle, including Challenger Lifts, Pro-Cut on-car brake lathes, as well as the new undercar equipment and broad diagnostic offerings. Snap-on equipment increased productivity for the automotive repair shop -- for automotive repair shop networks, an advantage rooted in our expanded and enhanced line of products. 
Finally, we continue to see further progress with our NEXIQ heavy-duty and fleet information systems as well as progress with the improved functionality and comprehensive content contained in Mitchell1's ProDemand and SureTrack products, all are differentiated -- differentiating offerings that lead to more business. Armed with those products, we achieved a number of multi-location customer wins in the quarter, displacing competitors and gaining traction across the marketplace. Snap-on information products, unique database solutions, effective navigation systems for speed to repair, all emphasizing our growing strength in vehicle information, and they help drive RS&I sales again this quarter. 
But that's the highlights. Significant progress was made in the quarter: organic sales rising 9.9% along all our runways for coherent growth; EPS of $1.87, up 15.4%; gains achieved through our Snap-on Value Creation Processes; RCI and customer connection shining -- especially shining through, strengthening our businesses and driving to a 16.7% opco operating margin, up 120 basis points. It was an encouraging quarter. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Aldo.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Nick. Our first quarter consolidated operating results are summarized on Slide 6. Net sales of $827.8 million in the quarter were up 9.9% organically, reflecting broad-based growth across all of our operating segments. On reported basis, net sales
componenttext:
Thanks, Nick. Our first quarter consolidated operating results are summarized on Slide 6. Net sales of $827.8 million in the quarter were up 9.9% organically, reflecting broad-based growth across all of our operating segments. On reported basis, net sales, including $38.5 million of unfavorable foreign currency translation, increased $40.3 million or 5.1% from 2014 levels. As you know, Snap-on has significant international operations and is subject to foreign currency translation fluctuations. Largely due to the recent strengthening of the U.S. dollar, foreign currency movements adversely impacted our year-over-year sales comparisons by approximately 540 basis points. Consolidated gross profit of $410.1 million increased $31.4 million from 2014 levels. Gross margin of 49.5% in the quarter improved 140 basis points, primarily due to benefits from higher sales, lower restructuring cost and savings from RCI initiatives. 
Operating expenses of $272.2 million increased $15.2 million, largely due to higher volume-related and other expenses, partially offset by savings from RCI initiatives. The operating expense margin of 32.8% increased 20 basis points from 2014 levels. No restructuring costs were incurred in the first 3 months of 2015. Last year, we incurred $2 million of restructuring costs. Pension expense in the quarter was approximately $2 million higher as compared to the prior year, reflecting updated pension plan assumptions for 2015, which include the effects of lower discount rates, as well as increased life expectancies. As a result of these factors, operating earnings before Financial Services of $137.9 million in the quarter, including $6.4 million of unfavorable foreign currency effects, increased $16.2 million from prior year levels as the percentage of sales improved 120 basis points to 16.7%. 
Financial Services revenue of $57.4 million in the quarter increased 14.3% from 2014 levels while operating earnings of $40.3 million increased 17.2%. The increases in both revenue and operating earnings primarily reflect the continued growth of the Financial Services portfolio. Consolidated operating earnings of $178.2 million in the quarter, including $6.9 million of unfavorable foreign currency effects, increased $22.1 million or 14.2%, and the operating margin of 20.1% improved 150 basis points from 18.6% a year ago. Our first quarter effective income tax rate of 32% compared with 31.6% last year. Finally, net earnings of $110.5 million or $1.87 per diluted share increased $14.6 million or $0.25 per share, representing a 15.4% increase in diluted earnings per share. 
Now let's turn to our segment results. Starting with the Commercial & Industrial, or C&I Group, on Slide 7. Sales of $297.5 million in the quarter were up 9.8% organically, primarily reflecting similar sales strength, both in critical industries and in our European-based hand tools business. Gross profit in the C&I Group totaled $116.5 million in the quarter, and the gross margin of 39.2% improved 40 basis points from 2014 levels, largely due to savings from RCI initiatives, primarily in Europe. Operating expenses of $72.5 million in the quarter decreased $1.1 million. The operating expense margin of 24.4% improved 90 basis points, largely due to sales volume leverage. As a result of these factors, operating earnings for the C&I segment of $44 million, including $1.3 million of unfavorable foreign currency effects, increased $4.9 million from 2014 levels. The operating margin of 14.8% improved 130 basis points. 
Turning now to Slide 8. First quarter sales in the Snap-on Tools Group of $378.2 million increased 12.9% organically, reflecting comparable sales gains in both the company's U.S. and international franchise operations. Gross profit of $166.3 million increased $18.3 million from 2014 levels, and the gross margin of 44% improved 90 basis points, primarily due to benefits from higher sales. Operating expenses of $106.5 million increased $7.7 million from 2014 levels, mostly due to higher volume-related expenses. The operating expense margin of 28.2% improved 60 basis points, principally due to sales volume leverage. As a result of these factors, operating earnings for the Snap-on Tools Group of $59.8 million, including $3 million of unfavorable foreign currency effects, increased $10.6 million, and the operating margin of 15.8% improved 150 basis points. 
Turning to the Repair, Systems & Information, RS&I Group, showed on Slide 9. Sales of $272.3 million in the quarter increased 6.3% organically from 2014 levels. The organic sales increase primarily reflects a high single-digit gain in sales of undercar equipment as well as mid-single-digit gains in both sales to OEM dealerships and the sales of diagnostic and repair information products to independent repair shop owners and managers. Gross profit of $127.3 million increased $9.3 million over 2014 levels, and gross margin of 46.8% improved 190 basis points, principally due to savings from RCI and other cost-reduction initiatives and $2 million of lower restructuring costs. Operating expenses totaled $63.4 million in the quarter. The operating expense margin of 23.3% increased 50 basis points, largely due to operating expenses of Pro-Cut, which was acquired in May of last year. First quarter operating earnings for the RS&I Group of $63.9 million, including $2.1 million of unfavorable foreign currency effects, increased $5.8 million or 10% from prior year levels, and the operating margin of 23.5% improved 140 basis points. 
Now turning to Slide 10. In the first quarter, operating earnings from Financial Services of $40.3 million on revenue of $57.4 million compared with operating earnings of $34.4 million on revenue of $50.2 million last year. The average yield on finance receivables of 17.7% in the quarter compared with 17.5% last year. The average yield on contract receivables was 9.5% in both periods. Originations of $230.7 million increased 14.2% from 2014 levels.
Moving to Slide 11. As of quarter-end, our balance sheet includes approximately $1.4 billion of gross financing receivables, including $1.2 billion of our U.S. Snap-on Credit operation. Approximately 80% of our U.S. financing portfolio relates to extended credit loans to technicians. During the quarter, our worldwide finance portfolio grew approximately $23 million. As for finance portfolio losses and delinquency trends, these continue to be in line with our expectations. 
Now turning to Slide 12. Cash provided by operations of $78.1 million in the quarter decreased $10.2 million from comparable 2014 levels, as higher net earnings in 2015 were more than offset by net increases in operating assets and liabilities, largely as a result of a $15 million discretionary domestic pension plan contribution as well as higher tax-related payments in the current year. Net cash used by investing activities of $59.5 million included $38.6 million to fund a net increase in finance receivables. Capital expenditures of $18.1 million in the quarter were comparable to the prior year.
Turning to Slide 13. Days sales outstanding for trade receivables of 60 days compared with 61 days at 2014 year-end. Inventories increased $6.8 million from 2014 year-end levels, primarily to support continued higher customer demand and new product introductions. On trailing 12-month basis, inventory turns of 3.6 compared with 3.7 turns at 2014 year-end. At quarter-end, cash position of $114.4 million decreased $18.5 million from 2014 year-end levels. Net decrease includes the impact of funding $198.8 million of new finance receivables, the repurchase of 340,000 shares for $49.7 million, dividend payments of $30.9 million and capital expenditures of $18.1 million. These cash decreases were partially offset by $160.2 million of cash from collections of finance receivables, $78.1 million of cash generated from operations and $22.8 million of cash from a net increase in short-term borrowings. Our net debt-to-cap ratio of 27.6% compared with 26.3% at 2014 year-end. In addition to our $114 million of cash and expected cash flow from operations, we have more than $700 million in available credit facilities, and our current short-term credit ratings allow us to access commercial paper markets. At first quarter-end, we had $52.5 million of commercial paper borrowings outstanding. 
This concludes my remarks on our first quarter performance. Now I'll turn the call over to Nick for his closing thoughts. Nick?

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Aldo. Now as our first quarter, similar to our other quarters, growth and improvement: EPS of $1.87, up 15.4%. Once again, there were headwinds, varying economies, fluctuating currencies and political unrest, but we overcame by finding and making
componenttext:
Thanks, Aldo. Now as our first quarter, similar to our other quarters, growth and improvement: EPS of $1.87, up 15.4%. Once again, there were headwinds, varying economies, fluctuating currencies and political unrest, but we overcame by finding and making the most of the opportunities. We've made significant progress along our runways for growth, driven by new products and new customers, enhanced the van channel. Tools Group organic sales up 12.9%, and we believe the network has never been stronger; expand with repair shop owners and managers. RS&I organic sales up 6.3%; OEM, dealerships and independent shops capturing new customers with a growing product bundle; extended critical industries and build in emerging markets; C&I organic sales up 9.8%. SNA Europe progressing against the economic tide; our critical industry team, building our understanding of those critical workplaces, launching new products aimed at those tasks and gaining position. 
Once again, again this quarter, we clearly saw the effects of Snap-on Value Creation, advancing down our runway for improvement. OI margin improvements are more than 100 basis points in every group, and an overall opco margin of 16.7%, an increase of 120 basis points. It was an encouraging quarter. We believe it serves as more testimony, great testimony, that our business models have the strength, our runways offer the opportunity and our teams have the capability to continue the trend of positive progress as we move forward even amid headwinds.
Before I turn the call over to the operator, it's appropriate that I mention our franchisees and associates. I know many of you are listening today. Encouraging performance of the first quarter and the positive trends are continuing due to your contribution and commitments. For the results you've offered -- authored, for the results you've authored, you have my congratulations. And for your dedication and support to our team, you have my thanks. 
Now I turn the call over to the operator. Operator?

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Tom Hayes with Northcoast Research.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Tom Hayes with Northcoast Research.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm just wondering, specifically on the C&I Group, great organic growth. I was just wondering if there are any industries that may be outperformed your expectations. And then earlier to that, just wondering about your exposure, maybe to oil and gas market
componenttext: I'm just wondering, specifically on the C&I Group, great organic growth. I was just wondering if there are any industries that may be outperformed your expectations. And then earlier to that, just wondering about your exposure, maybe to oil and gas market as they kind of have some challenges right now.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, look. I expect good news in every market every quarter, I think, because we're not -- the thing is we're in early days in penetrating critical industries. It's an aspect of coherent growth that what we are doing there is duplicating what we have done
componenttext: Yes, look. I expect good news in every market every quarter, I think, because we're not -- the thing is we're in early days in penetrating critical industries. It's an aspect of coherent growth that what we are doing there is duplicating what we have done for automotive repair technicians all these years. We're doing them for other people in other industries, observing work and making it easier with just the right tools, whether it's software or hardware. And so the -- an element of that is learning about the industry. So it's early days. Now we have varying industries in there, aviation, the military, oil and gas, power generation, mining. One of the advantages of this is we don't really have much [indiscernible] in the way of share in these businesses, so therefore, each quarter rise and fall is not so much on the effect of the industry. Just on our own performance. So we have lumpiness from section to section or from industry to industry. In this particular quarter, we actually saw fine performance in places, like I said in my -- power generation, mining, railroads, the military. The military was up this time, because we were able to see opportunities. Aviation is a big business in that area. And oil and gas actually, actually was up even slightly in this quarter. So we saw the usual lumpiness from operation to operation, but the critical industries business really isn't the driver behind C&I, and you see the C&I growth across those segments. So I didn't see any particular surprises. I guess if you were looking at our business, you might say, "Gee, they grew in oil and gas even though the market was weak." My view was we don't have that big a share in oil and gas, therefore, we can grow against weak markets.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Just one kind of follow-up question. I'm just wondering on the -- how much share repurchase authorization you still have.
componenttext: Okay, great. Just one kind of follow-up question. I'm just wondering on the -- how much share repurchase authorization you still have.

componenttext: We have about $215 million.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Liam Burke with Wunderlich.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Liam Burke with Wunderlich.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: The organic growth in the Snap-on Tool segment is pretty strong, closer to the high single digits, a lot higher than more of a mid-single-digit expectation. What's driving that incremental growth?
componenttext: The organic growth in the Snap-on Tool segment is pretty strong, closer to the high single digits, a lot higher than more of a mid-single-digit expectation. What's driving that incremental growth?

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think what's driving it is that the Tools Group team is understanding how to enable the franchisees that we have in various places. We have 4,800 worldwide. We have 3,478, I think, in the United States are van. And they're learning quarter-by-quar
componenttext: Well, I think what's driving it is that the Tools Group team is understanding how to enable the franchisees that we have in various places. We have 4,800 worldwide. We have 3,478, I think, in the United States are van. And they're learning quarter-by-quarter, how to do it better, and that's allowed them to sell more to same customers and reach other customers, which they had on their routes, but they hadn't been calling on. So the effects are these, I think -- maybe threefold. One effect is, I think we've talked about it many times, they're -- I think they're very cleverly breaking through the natural boundaries of that model by adding space with the Rock 'N Roll cabs, and you can see it in the progression of the tool storage, and breaking through the time by adding help with things like the TechKnow vans. And now we have -- I think we have 66, 67 Rock 'N Roll -- 66 Rock 'N Roll vans throughout the world now. And we have now up to 35 TechKnow vans, up about 4 since last quarter. And so you can see breaking that natural boundary is helping. Secondly, boy, we're using as much as possible our customer connection. We spend a lot of time in the shops, and  we're organizing that process in getting that information back into the innovation process and rolling out new products like that 36-inch Breaker Bar. People might look at that and say, "What's that? It's just a long bar." But the idea was it wasn't really available on the marketplace, and the ones that were available aren't as comfortable. Innovation doesn't have to be earth shattering. It just has to make work easier in this space. And the tools group is understanding how to do that. And then thirdly, they're looking at the franchisee and saying, "We know your time is valuable. We're going to make it better. We're going to drive our RCI into the vans." And that's all resulting in this kind of thing. Their numbers were up 12.8% in the quarter -- 12.9% in the quarter, 11.8% the quarter before that, 6% the quarter before that, 6.6% the quarter before that and 6% before that. In fact, 19 of the last 20 quarters, they've been 6% or above. And that's -- what's driving it all is tuning that business. You know what? It's kind of -- if you step back and you look at the auto repair, you would say it's going to go better than GDP. 4% to 6% is what we say. But if you have capability that resonates with those franchisees like they figured out, you see these kind of numbers.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And you touched on RCI across all businesses. They were providing incremental profitability, along with volume increases. Can you push RCI in a similar fashion of the van channel?
componenttext: Okay. And you touched on RCI across all businesses. They were providing incremental profitability, along with volume increases. Can you push RCI in a similar fashion of the van channel?

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. That's what we're doing. We're putting RCI into the van drivers. Things like -- I think I've mentioned this before in the call, but things like when you repair a ratchet. Repairing a ratchet was taking 15 minutes, every ratchet. Sometimes I was on v
componenttext: Sure. That's what we're doing. We're putting RCI into the van drivers. Things like -- I think I've mentioned this before in the call, but things like when you repair a ratchet. Repairing a ratchet was taking 15 minutes, every ratchet. Sometimes I was on vans where people brought on 4 different -- 4 ratchets and you repair it at one stop. That would've killed the route that day. But we have tools, kind of just like a factory, laying it out like a factory. Like our van drivers can repair it in 3 or 4 minutes now. And a number of things like that. So taking RCI, looking at the van, doing value stream mapping on the van and reducing the time, adding to their selling time as part of the process, which is allowing them to reach out to more customers. That's exactly what we've been doing. Thanks for that question.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from David Leiker with Baird.
componenttext: Next question comes from David Leiker with Baird.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Joe Vruwink for David. Maybe staying with the Tools Group for a second. Any products in the catalog that's become kind of logical extensions of this recent company-owned van strategy? I should say additional...
componenttext: This is Joe Vruwink for David. Maybe staying with the Tools Group for a second. Any products in the catalog that's become kind of logical extensions of this recent company-owned van strategy? I should say additional...

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't think so. I think not any particular product. I don't think -- I'm sure I could go through our launching of new products and find those that came from a company-owned store driver. In fact, I'd -- but only around customer connection. We have the v
componenttext: I don't think so. I think not any particular product. I don't think -- I'm sure I could go through our launching of new products and find those that came from a company-owned store driver. In fact, I'd -- but only around customer connection. We have the van driver ourself is the guy -- the guy is an employee, goes out there and he reports back as part of -- he gives us leads for a new tool as part of the company-owned stores, and that falls back. But we don't really differentiate between a lead from a company-owned store and a franchisee. But in my remarks, you might've heard the whole idea of the power tool drawer organizer at the bottom -- at the tool storage box, that came from the Rock 'N Roll cab. We have these -- and their company stores. They're not selling, but their company stores are rolling around. People got on those Rock 'N Roll cabs, and they started talking about, "Boy, wouldn't it be good if we have power tool organizer at the bottom -- in one of these drawers?" We got that idea. We give it to the engineers. They put in place. And we're rolling out this new product, and it's looking to be a good seller. So that's an example. I guess the only thing is if you have the company-owned stores, they just add to the flow of ideas back from the field, the customer connection that comes back from the field.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I guess my question was more oriented towards the Rock 'N Roll cab and the TechKnow van put really a spotlight on particular things. Is there some extension of that strategy that you can keep rolling out across the Tools Group?
componenttext: So I guess my question was more oriented towards the Rock 'N Roll cab and the TechKnow van put really a spotlight on particular things. Is there some extension of that strategy that you can keep rolling out across the Tools Group?

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we only have -- we have 35 TechKnow vans now. We actually added a couple Rock 'N Roll cabs in the last quarter, so that's growing much more slowly. But we added 4 TechKnow vans, so they may continue to grow some. Whether we add another extension, we
componenttext: Well, we only have -- we have 35 TechKnow vans now. We actually added a couple Rock 'N Roll cabs in the last quarter, so that's growing much more slowly. But we added 4 TechKnow vans, so they may continue to grow some. Whether we add another extension, we may have some ideas. But I don't think I'm going to preannounce them on the call here. I think that's the magic of the magicians, to try to find out more techniques and activities or programs that would expand the power of the franchisees. See, I think one of the things that I just want to point out. Part of the -- really, what the Tools Group has done is they figured out that these vans, these franchisees, are a great resource. They're better than anybody else's. And they figured out how to help them be more powerful and amplify that power of that rolling retail space and that really capable and committed entrepreneur that's driving it. And we're going to do more of that, but I'm not about to announce any more of that.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. And then switching gears over to the profitability in RS&I this quarter. You called out a few product areas that I would normally think are a bit lower margin within that segment, yet the margins improved year-over-year. Has RCI kind of
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And then switching gears over to the profitability in RS&I this quarter. You called out a few product areas that I would normally think are a bit lower margin within that segment, yet the margins improved year-over-year. Has RCI kind of neutralized thinking about that business in terms of software being sold or equipment being sold from an EBIT margin standpoint?

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: As I've said many times on these calls, RS&I is the hardest to characterize from a margin perspective. Yes, we had good growth and things like equipment, which tends to be lower margin, but we had a good quarter in software that offset it, our software is
componenttext: As I've said many times on these calls, RS&I is the hardest to characterize from a margin perspective. Yes, we had good growth and things like equipment, which tends to be lower margin, but we had a good quarter in software that offset it, our software is rolling. When I go out and talk to people, they love our diagnostics. There's -- in many cases, they're solving problems 3x or 4x faster than anybody else, 3x or 4x faster than anybody else, and the software is up. So that's good stuff. Our Mitchell1 information business and our diagnostics and the independent garages are pretty robust. And yes, okay, equipment's growing, but those 2 things are relatively in balance. So I don't think we saw a lot of mix in those numbers except for maybe the acquisition might have dinged it a little bit. Now the story of 140 basis points in -- I think it's 140 basis points in RS&I is we had about 50 60 of -- or about 15 60 of RCI and we had -- I think we had 70 or 80 of restructuring. Because last year, we had a big restructuring dollop in there. So that's why you can kind of vaguely look at that, but still a pretty big dollop of RCI. Plus, you want to make no mistake about this. Even though the equipment, the lower-margin businesses are growing, so is the software.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Gary Prestopino with Barrington Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Gary Prestopino with Barrington Research.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Nick, it's the inevitable question on margins. And just looking at the gross margin, I think that gross margin you reported in Q1 was probably the highest that it's been for quite some time. And I was just wondering if there were something in there that g
componenttext: Nick, it's the inevitable question on margins. And just looking at the gross margin, I think that gross margin you reported in Q1 was probably the highest that it's been for quite some time. And I was just wondering if there were something in there that got it above 49% or is -- onetime deal. Or are we at a new kind of sustainable level here? If you directly -- can you talk of that?

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Look, I don't -- we don't spend a lot of time agonizing over the difference between gross margin and OE. I kind of test the operations to drive their operating income, and I tend to focus on that much more. And what we've said is that we believe that
componenttext: Yes. Look, I don't -- we don't spend a lot of time agonizing over the difference between gross margin and OE. I kind of test the operations to drive their operating income, and I tend to focus on that much more. And what we've said is that we believe that we have both runways for growth and improvement at accrued operating income. And from quarter to quarter, they accrue -- those 2 things accrue in different proportions between gross margin and operating expense. So I wouldn't call the gross margin necessarily breakthrough, but there's nothing special in there this quarter. There's nothing really -- there's no real -- I don't think there's any real onetime event or anything like that. Really, I mean, you saw our currency numbers in the quarter. I think our sales were, what was it, 38.5% in currency and about 6.9% in OI. And we're -- we are -- we have currency headwinds. And if the current rates stay the same, those will rise. But on the other hand, we believe that that's sort of arithmetic. We're so enthusiastic about our operating opportunities, and you can see it in this quarter how the operating opportunities worked out. Currencies are going to go up and down, but the operating gains are going to stay with us forever. And we view the 16.7% as being part of that.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's fair. And then Europe. I've been reading that new car registrations are up. It seems that Europe is starting to get some traction, and I think you said your European hand tools business top line was up commensurate with C&I. So is -- has the
componenttext: Okay, that's fair. And then Europe. I've been reading that new car registrations are up. It seems that Europe is starting to get some traction, and I think you said your European hand tools business top line was up commensurate with C&I. So is -- has the -- the cadence have been that you've moved on a quarterly basis over the last couple of quarters from low single-digit to mid-single-digit to high single-digit growth in...

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: It hasn't been that -- I don't think it's been that -- thinking about it back here, I have to go back and look at it, but I don't think it's been that sort of straight line. But if you look at it over, say, like 8 quarters or something like that, you prob
componenttext: It hasn't been that -- I don't think it's been that -- thinking about it back here, I have to go back and look at it, but I don't think it's been that sort of straight line. But if you look at it over, say, like 8 quarters or something like that, you probably see some kind of movement. I think what happened this quarter is basically some of our activities are paying off associated with new product development. We do have some new product that are exciting to customers. You can create enthusiasm even in what I consider to be a relatively dead market in Europe. New car sales usually doesn't help us that much except for the fact that -- except for the broader fact that new car sales is probably accompanying a more positive economy. It is true though that we made, I think, encouraging gains in selling in Europe. We -- France and Germany, which had been a drag in the last couple of quarters, in fact, they were down in the last couple of quarters, they were up this quarter. And we continued with the Nordic countries, and we had some business in Turkey. Of course, Eastern Europe was weak. So -- and Spain was up off of a relatively low base. So we kind of saw the same progress in Europe that we've seen in other quarters, except we started making progress in France and Germany. Eastern Europe is kind of dead right now. It's not just difficult and so on. So that -- it's kind of what we saw. So I guess you could be entitled to the idea Europe got somewhat better, but profits were even better, very strong performance because of the effects of RCI.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's great news. And then lastly, as I just look at this -- the reported revenues and the unfavorable currency translation. If I add back the impact of currency translation and then say you have about 25% of your sales are based internationally, is that
componenttext: That's great news. And then lastly, as I just look at this -- the reported revenues and the unfavorable currency translation. If I add back the impact of currency translation and then say you have about 25% of your sales are based internationally, is that correct?

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: A little more than that, I think. It's -- let me see, I think it's about, what is it, like 60 -- 35%. 35% is the international.
componenttext: A little more than that, I think. It's -- let me see, I think it's about, what is it, like 60 -- 35%. 35% is the international.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Because I was getting a currency hit of somewhere between 17% drag on the numbers from a 25% contribution. So it's 35%. It's still going to be about a 10% to 12% hit. And I'm just wondering where the -- was the euro down that much that it caused tha
componenttext: Okay. Because I was getting a currency hit of somewhere between 17% drag on the numbers from a 25% contribution. So it's 35%. It's still going to be about a 10% to 12% hit. And I'm just wondering where the -- was the euro down that much that it caused that kind of drag on the numbers? Or is my math wrong?

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: The euro was down. We have several currencies that impact this on a translation basis. You've got -- first of all, you've got the euro, and then you've got the pound and then you've got the Canadian dollar. I'll say look at that. And actually, when I said
componenttext: The euro was down. We have several currencies that impact this on a translation basis. You've got -- first of all, you've got the euro, and then you've got the pound and then you've got the Canadian dollar. I'll say look at that. And actually, when I said 35%, I was embracing our northern neighbors here and I was using Canada. If you just look at the United States, talk about -- if you think of Canada as international, which is somehow I don't really always, it's 40% outside the United States. So Canada is in there. So you see those kind of variations. I mean, basically, one of those companies that is current -- we are affected by currency, but we have some good -- some regional natural hedges from transactions because we tend to make in the markets where we sell.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. That's the next question I was going to get to. You have those natural hedges, so...
componenttext: Right. That's the next question I was going to get to. You have those natural hedges, so...

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, not in everything. We're not immune. Sort of like this, we're currency-resistant from a transaction point of view, but we're not immune. So we don't wring our hands over it. We see it coming, like I said. Clearly, we had currency last year actually. W
componenttext: No, not in everything. We're not immune. Sort of like this, we're currency-resistant from a transaction point of view, but we're not immune. So we don't wring our hands over it. We see it coming, like I said. Clearly, we had currency last year actually. We've got it this year. If the rates stay where they are, we'll rise some. But it doesn't affect our operating activity, because we know that 16.7% is going to stay with us, that 12.9% is going to stay with us, that 9.8% is going to stay with us.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Richard Hilgert with Morningstar.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Richard Hilgert with Morningstar.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was looking at the currency impact a little bit differently. I added back the currency impacts to each one of the revenues for each of the groups and then also added back the negative impact for currency for each one of their operating results. The year
componenttext: I was looking at the currency impact a little bit differently. I added back the currency impacts to each one of the revenues for each of the groups and then also added back the negative impact for currency for each one of their operating results. The year-over-year increase or expansion in margin, excluding currency, was 140 basis points. When I did all those add-backs, I came up with an expansion that was just about 10 basis points less than that, at about 130, which is still fantastic performance. But I'm curious, is that because -- and correct me if I'm wrong, but isn't C&I a little bit more of the mix when you add back the currencies and that's why the expansion wasn't quite as much when you take into consideration the currency?

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll tell you this. I'll tell you this is that in our numbers, 120 basis points per our calculations, no effect of currency in that 120. In other words, it all balances out at the corporate level. At the corporate level, it all balances out. So we don't r
componenttext: I'll tell you this. I'll tell you this is that in our numbers, 120 basis points per our calculations, no effect of currency in that 120. In other words, it all balances out at the corporate level. At the corporate level, it all balances out. So we don't really -- at a margin level, at a margin rate level. So the 16.7% from our perspective is basically all -- it's pretty much -- it's got bad news from pension. It's got bad news from pension and so on, and it's primarily RCI and volume productivity.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. No matter how you slice it, it's still a great performance.
componenttext: Yes. No matter how you slice it, it's still a great performance.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's got a little bit restructuring, good news, offsetting pension, and the rest is productivity. Currency doesn't come in there.  But if you go by the various groups, C&I has helped a little bit on a margin rate basis, not on an absolute basis, by curren
componenttext: It's got a little bit restructuring, good news, offsetting pension, and the rest is productivity. Currency doesn't come in there.  But if you go by the various groups, C&I has helped a little bit on a margin rate basis, not on an absolute basis, by currency, Tools Group being -- Tools Group, if they didn't have currency, Tools Group would be much more -- it would've been more than 150 basis points, and RS&I, a little bit of currency. But that's the way it kind of works out.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the hand tools side. Since we've had improving economic conditions for the last 3, 4 years now, is this -- have you seen an increase in the number of garages opening up in United States? Does that also help?
componenttext: Okay. And then on the hand tools side. Since we've had improving economic conditions for the last 3, 4 years now, is this -- have you seen an increase in the number of garages opening up in United States? Does that also help?

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. Technician -- the technician population is probably growing at about 1.3%. For government work, that'll be the number. But the garages -- in fact, if anything, actually, depending on how far back you go, the dealerships have shrunk. I think the dealer
componenttext: No. Technician -- the technician population is probably growing at about 1.3%. For government work, that'll be the number. But the garages -- in fact, if anything, actually, depending on how far back you go, the dealerships have shrunk. I think the dealerships were about 21,000 before recession. Now they're at 17,000 or -- between 17,000 and 18,000. So they shrunk. The independents have stayed about the same. The independents have taken more share since -- that started before the recession. That seems to maybe -- this date always trails, so that's kind of leveled off a lot of people think now. But I think there hasn't been a big change in the characteristics, except the independents are becoming more sophisticated because they have to deal with the changing technologies. 20 years ago, there were 50 engine codes on a car. Now there's 5,000 engine codes. Every -- it's hard to fix a car without a diagnostic unit now, and we have the best one. And so we're selling them to technicians now, not just to garages, and so that's helping drive our business. So that technology change in the independent space, that's why I talked about the diagnostic workstation. Because the independent garages know that people know their cars are more like spaceships these days, and they want to bring them to people who can fix them. And therefore, this diagnostic unit makes it look like, "Wow, this is big computer here that can fix the car, help fix the car." And it grows confidence and actually helps in terms of accuracy. So if anything, we're seeing a greater demand of our products in the independent shops and other shops because of the changing technology. That's the big change.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then with respect to your comments about Europe and new car sales and what that means in terms of hand tool sales over there. Just noticing Western Europe trailing 12 months new car sales are up about 6%. Eastern Europe, however though, i
componenttext: Okay, great. And then with respect to your comments about Europe and new car sales and what that means in terms of hand tool sales over there. Just noticing Western Europe trailing 12 months new car sales are up about 6%. Eastern Europe, however though, is up about 10%. They were up as much as 15% back -- about -- or around the third quarter, so last year, but that growth rate has kind of steadily gone down a bit. They're still tracking year-over-year increases. So I'm kind of curious. It makes sense that France and Germany, you're doing better. The industry is doing better in general in those 2 countries. But I'm surprised that Eastern Europe hasn't really kept up with the expansion of the new car demand. Any comments about that?

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: But new car demand is down in Eastern Europe, right?
componenttext: But new car demand is down in Eastern Europe, right?

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, it's still up.
componenttext: No, it's still up.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Still up. But for us, for us, new cars don't matter. I mean, I think I said that. Because the new car sales are almost always -- except in emerging markets, places like China and India and so on, they're almost always small compared to the install base of
componenttext: Still up. But for us, for us, new cars don't matter. I mean, I think I said that. Because the new car sales are almost always -- except in emerging markets, places like China and India and so on, they're almost always small compared to the install base of the car park. Consider the U.S., $16 million (sic) [16 million] cars, 16 -- North America, what, 17 million, 18 million cars sold. There's 300 million on the road. It's like a fly speck almost, the new cars, compared to those other roads. So it doesn't really move our business that much up and down and in sort of a short wave basis. In terms of Eastern Europe, I think I would just suggest to you that -- I'm not really sure what's going on in Eastern Europe. It's a cocktail of different countries, so it's really hard to say. I mean, you see Russia being so weak. On the other hand, our business is up in Poland, for example, if you include that in Eastern Europe, so...

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I do.
componenttext: Yes, I do.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's hard to make much prediction about that. I think this is just one of those turbulent things that where traditional economics don't always work in every period.
componenttext: It's hard to make much prediction about that. I think this is just one of those turbulent things that where traditional economics don't always work in every period.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: Okay. And just for clarification on new car sales that would impact you from the perspective of the new diagnostic and the new tools that have to come out to service new vehicles, right?

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, sure, but that's a longer wave event. In other words, you're right, Richard, but the next year isn't that much different. It changes some, and so people need to adjust for that. But these things work through over time. I was reacting to the idea tha
componenttext: Sure, sure, but that's a longer wave event. In other words, you're right, Richard, but the next year isn't that much different. It changes some, and so people need to adjust for that. But these things work through over time. I was reacting to the idea that people say, "Well, new car sales are up in the first quarter, therefore, your business is going to be better." I don't think so. It doesn't affect us that much. So much longer -- yes.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: And last question for Aldo. The Financial Services business, the receivables. That year-over-year keeps growing at low double-digit numbers despite the lower revenue and the single-digit numbers. Any comments on how come we're still seeing so much more growth? I thought that the Financial Services business was pretty much penetrated for being a captive now.

headline: Snap-on Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: Richard, just to remind you, most of the activity in Financial Services, actually about 94%, 95% of it, really reflects activity in the Snap-on Tools Group. So if you look at Snap-on Tools Group performance, again, it was, I think, organically 12-plus percent, 12.9%. And I think what you're seeing when you look at originations of 14.2% in the top line portfolio growth, you're seeing it really reflective of the Tools Group and the Financial Services penetration of their sale of not just big-ticket items, but a variety of the products that they sell. So over time, it'll mirror that. And I think if you look back, it's rather consistent with the Tools Group performance over the last several quarters.
